what might this mean for how we reconstruct non-rhinoceratine rhinos? hard to say without further research, but it makes it hard to just assume a fossil rhino has a horn because its nose is rugose. 11/15

so, elasmothere skulls don‚Äôt show the same pattern of bone associated with rhino-like projecting horns, and their ‚Äúhorns‚Äù are not homologous based on our current understanding of the shape of rhino evolution. 10/15

elasmotheres are a group of rhinos that seem to diverge in the late oligocene. gaindatherium, the first unambiguously horned rhino and earliest rhinoceratinae, diverged in the mid miocene. elasmotheres and living rhinos seem to have evolved their ‚Äúhorns‚Äù independently. 9/15

any kind of rugosity on an extinct rhino‚Äôs nose (or cheeks for iranotherium) has been used as evidence for horns, but rough textures can correlate to many different hardened skin structures seen in other animals. 6/15 https://t.co/t6b6enej32

this is seen in the tall horns of all extant animals mentioned above, but is absent in very young rhinos or those with flat horns, who‚Äôs condition may be closer to what's seen in taxa with bosses like muskox.¬† so there are consistent bone correlates for tall horns. 5/15 https://t.co/orqfskosc5

rhino horns grow out from their base in a conical shape. the center of the horn is stronger tissue rich in calcium and melanin, and the outside is made up of dead keratin that gets worn away by uv exposure or abrasion. this forms overall the shape of the horn 3/15 https://t.co/dgazgwtwvf

projecting epidermal structures made entirely of keratin without an internal support like rhino ‚Äúhorns‚Äù are pretty rare in living animals. outside of rhinos, similar structures are seen in comb ducks and american white pelicans. 2/15 https://t.co/rihuvgpwhz
